waiting.title: Welcome to $t(appNameWithDefiniteArticle)!
text: Thanks for trusting the open-source $t(appName)! But always remember:

waiting.title: How do I use this guide?
text: You can toggle this guide with the button in the upper right corner. If you are new to cryptocurrencies, though, we recommend that you leave the guide open for now. :-)

waiting.title: How can I get a device?
text: You can buy a BitBox in our online shop:

waiting.title: Does this app require an Internet connection?
text: Yes, an Internet connection is required to synchronize the wallet with the blockchain and send transactions.

waiting.title: Which servers does this app talk to?
text: This app communicates with servers of Shift Cryptosecurity to check for updates, load transactions, and send information to paired mobile apps.

waiting.title: Can I use the app without your servers?
text: Not at the moment but we are working on letting you configure servers of your own!

waitingWithoutDevice.title: Can I use the app without a device?
text: Unfortunately, this is not yet possible at the moment.
Luckily, you are currently in developer mode and can simply enter a PIN, from which a seed is derived deterministically (i.e. without additional randomness).

accountEmpty.title: Why is my account empty?
accountEmpty.text: Your account is still empty because you have not yet received any {{unit}}. Buy some from an exchange or from a friend first.

accountReceive.title: How can I get more {{unit}}?
accountReceive.text: Click the receive button in the upper right corner and send the displayed address to an exchange or to a friend.

accountSendDisabled.title: Why can't I send any {{unit}}?
accountSendDisabled.text: Your balance may not be zero, otherwise you cannot even cover the transaction fee.

accountTransactionLabel.title: What is the character sequence displayed for each transaction?
accountTransactionLabel.text: It is the address which the coins have been sent to or received on. An address encodes how (and thus by whom) the coins can be spent.

accountTransactionTime.title: How is the time determined?
accountTransactionTime.text: It is the timestamp of the block with which the transaction has been added to the blockchain.

accountTransactionDetails.title: How can I see more details for a transaction?
accountTransactionDetails.text: Move the mouse over the transaction and click on the expand area.

accountTransactionAttributes.title: What is the info shown in the transaction details?
text: The number of confirmations shows the number of blocks that have been added to the block that contains the transaction. We recommend that you wait for at least three confirmations before you consider a payment as settled.

The transaction ID is the hash of the whole transaction. It is useful to look up a transaction in an external block explorer in order to verify its authenticity (in case you don't trust us, which you shouldn't).
The virtual size of a transaction is used to determine its fee. You have successfully saved on fees if it is smaller than the size of the transaction.
The size of a transaction describes its actual size in bytes when serialized according to the Bitcoin protocol.

The weight of a transaction has been introduced with Segwit, and is a new metric to evaluate transaction and block sizes. Each segregated witness byte counts as one, everything else as four weight units. Instead of one megabyte in actual size, the block size limit is now four million weight units.
The fee is the amount that has been paid to the miner that included the transaction in a block. Click on the send button to read more about why there is a fee at all.

accountIncomingBalance.title: What does incoming mean?
accountIncomingBalance.text: Incoming sums up the amounts that are being transferred to you but have not yet been confirmed by the network.

accountTransactionConfirmation.title: Why must transactions be confirmed by the network?
accountTransactionConfirmation.text: In order to ensure that a coin (respectively transaction output) cannot be spent more than once, so-called miners continuously vote on the history of transactions by mining (and thus adding) blocks. If the chain of blocks diverges, honest participants converge on the longest branch containing only valid transactions. Since blocks are computationally difficult to find, each block confirms all preceding blocks on its branch. The more confirmations there are, the harder it is for an attacker to mine a distinct branch on which the coins are spent differently.

receive.title: What do I do with an address?
text: Give it to others to send you some coins.
(Try to independently verify the address, for example with a phone call, as an attacker could send an address which does not belong to you to the payer otherwise.)

receive.title: Why are there so many addresses?
text: For privacy and security reasons, you should never hand out the same address twice. Click on 'Next' to get a new address for a different purpose. (Think of addresses like invoice numbers.)

receive.title: Why are there at most 20 addresses?
text: All addresses are derived from a single seed, which you backed up when setting up the device. The backup, however, is only useful if all your addresses and thus your funds can be recovered. Since you can derive a virtually unlimited number of addresses, the search has to stop somewhere. The convention is to stop the search after 20 unused addresses in a row.

receive.title: What do I do with the pixelated black and white image?
text: It is a so-called QR code, which can easily be scanned by mobile phones and which encodes the address as written below it. If the person who wants to send you coins is present, showing the QR code is easier than sending the address manually.

receive.title: Why should I verify the address securely?
text: The whole reason for buying a hardware wallet like the BitBox is because you don't trust your computer due to its big attack surface. Consequently, you should also not trust your computer to generate and display authentic addresses. The button to verify the address securely makes the BitBox send the address to a paired mobile phone, from which you can also scan and verify the QR code.

receive.title: How can I verify an address securely?
text: Click on the BitBox icon in the sidebar on the left and see the Pairing section. Continue reading the guide over there.

receive.title: Why and when do the addresses change?
text: As soon as one of the addresses is used in a transaction, new addresses are added to the list so that you have again 20 unused addresses available.

send.title: Which address do I enter?
text: Ask the person or organization you would like to send some coins to for a receiving address. For privacy and security reasons, you should use that address only once.

Also never send coins to an address from which you received them! Besides reusing an already used address, you don't know whether the recipient (still) controls the corresponding private key and the recipient may not know that the transfer came from you.

send.title: Why is there a network fee?
text: Since blockchains are open and decentralized, anyone can send transactions. In order to prevent the network from being flooded with spam transactions, there is a continuous auction for being included by a miner into the next block. The more transactions are pending for confirmation, the higher the transaction fee.

Miners vote on the history of transactions. Since there is no trusted third party to enforce one vote per person (which is the whole point of blockchains), miners vote on transactions by sacrificing a costly resource like computing power. As a reward for their work, they can claim newly created coins and the fee of all the transactions they included.

send.title: What is the network priority?
text: Since the space in each block is limited, miners are economically incentivized to include the transactions which have the highest fee per byte (and not per amount like traditional payment services). The higher fee you are willing to pay, the faster your transaction is typically confirmed by the network.

send.title: How is the fee determined?
text: Depending on the network priority that you choose, we calculate the fee based on the size (respectively weight) of the transaction. We have the following fee targets, whose values are determined by Bitcoin Core and which are only shown if they have a different value from the target below.
Economy: 24 blocks (around 4 hours for Bitcoin, 1 hour for Litecoin)
Low: 12 blocks (around 2 hours for Bitcoin, 30 minutes for Litecoin)
Normal: 6 blocks (around 1 hour for Bitcoin, 15 minutes for Litecoin)
High: 2 blocks (around 20 minutes for Bitcoin, 5 minutes for Litecoin)
(A block takes on average ten minutes for Bitcoin (2.5 minutes in Litecoin) to mine and the network load may vary considerably in the above periods.)

send.title: Can I revert a transaction?
text: Once a transaction is signed and sent (i.e. broadcasted to the network), it can no longer be reverted. Verify the transactions (including the fee) properly before signing!
If you know the recipient and he or she is willing to send the same amount (minus the transaction fees) back to you, you can send them a new receiving address.

settings.title: Can I have more accounts than shown to the left?
text: Unfortunately, this is not yet supported. Stay tuned.

settings.title: What is Bitcoin Legacy?
text: This uses an old transaction format, which has been superseded by the Segwit accounts.

settings.title: What is Bitcoin Segwit?
text: This uses a new transaction format which incurs less network fees. It is a transitional account, as it uses the same address format, and as such can be used with all existing Bitcoin wallets/exchanges/services.

settings.title: What is Bitcoin Native Segwit?
text: To reap the full benefits, Native Segwit should be used. It uses a new address format called Bech32, but this format is not accepted everywhere yet.

bitbox.title: How to securely pair with your phone
text: After having downloaded our mobile app for either iOS or Android, you scan the displayed QR code, which sets up a secure channel between the mobile app and this application. Afterwards, a secret key shared between the mobile phone and the BitBox is generated. Just follow the instructions in the mobile app.

bitbox.title: What is a hidden wallet?
text: It is a second wallet on the same device protected by a different PIN which you can use for plausible deniability.

backups.title: What is a backup?
text: It is a copy of the seed on an SD card.

backups.title: Can I encrypt the backup?
text: No but your recovery password is required to derive the wallet from the stored seed.

unlock.title: I have a password, but not a PIN. What do I need to do?
text: If you set up your BitBox previously with a password, you can use it to unlock the device. Just enter it in the PIN input field.

unlock.title: What do I do if I forgot the PIN?
text: You have to reset the device and restore the wallet from a backup.

unlock.title: How do I reset the device?
text: Enter a wrong PIN 15 times. The last few attempts require a long touch on the device.

initialize.title: What is the PIN used for?
text: The PIN is used to authenticate access to the device and to encrypt the communication.

initialize.title: What happens if I forget the PIN?
text: If you forget the PIN, you have to reset the device and restore the wallet from a backup.

seed.title: What shall I do with the SD card?
text: Store it somewhere safe and do not insert it to your computer! You bought the BitBox hardware wallet because your computer is too vulnerable to handle private keys for cryptocurrencies.

seed.title: Can I print the backup on the SD card?
text: You can as the seed is stored in a PDF on the SD card. However, you should either insert the SD card directly into a non-networked printer or use a different computer, which ideally is never online. Alternatively, you can back up the seed on several SD cards instead.

seed.title: Why can't I change the recovery password later on?
text: The recovery password is used for key derivation and not seed encryption. If you enter a different password, a different wallet is derived.
